wikipedia_page.main: Sir Evelyn Freeth (25 May 1846 – 16 September 1911) was an English civil servant who became an expert on death duties. In his youth he was a keen sportsman who played football against Scotland in the first representative match in March 1870.

response: Several members of the Civil Service took a prominent role in organising the first representative matches between sides representing England and Scotland in 1870. The captain of the first Scottish XI was James Kirkpatrick (later Sir James Kirkpatrick, 8th Baronet) who included fellow civil servants Charles and William Baillie-Hamilton and William Lindsay in the team, while the England XI included William C. Butler and Evelyn Freeth.

response: Robert Evelyn Freeth AARE  (b Dublin 7 April 1886 - d Perth, WA 16 September 1979)Freeth Notes was an Anglican priestCrockford's Clerical Directory 1955-56 p408:  Oxford: OUP, 1955 and educator.GGS

Freeth was the son of Evelyn Freeth, a civil servant who became an expert on death duties. He was educated at Selwyn College, Cambridge and ordained in 1910. After missionary service in Melanesia he served his title at Christ Church, North Adelaide. He was Priest in charge of Angaston from 1914 to 1915. He then taught at King's School, Parramatta; St Andrew's Cathedral School, Sydney; Sydney Church of England Grammar School; and Guildford Grammar School, Perth, where he was Head Master from 1928 to 1950. He became Archdeacon of Perth, WA in 1952; and Assistant Bishop of Perth in 1957. He retired in 1963.

Born Elizabeth Oakes Freeth at the King's School, Parramatta, New South Wales, on 13 April 1918, Mitchell was the daughter of Robert Freeth, an Anglican priest and educator, and Gladys Mary Freeth (née Snashall). Her paternal grandfather was Sir Evelyn Freeth and her older brother was Sir Gordon Freeth.
